elements.content: An exceptionally stable metal–organic framework based on one-dimensional (1D) TbIII chains with significant green emission under excitation energy, {[Tb­(TATMA)­(H2O)·2H2O} n (namely, 1), has been fabricated successfully under hydrothermal conditions. By virtue of the spectral overlap between the absorbance spectra of nitrofurans (NFAs) and the excitation spectrum of MOF 1, the resultant sample exhibits outstandingly sensitive and selective luminescence detectability for NFT (K sv = 3.35 × 104 M–1) and NFZ (K sv = 3.00 × 104 M–1) by quenching phenomenon. More importantly, it can detect NFAs in water from bovine serum samples. The portable MOF film can be easily prepared and used with excellent stability and recursitivity.

By virtue of the spectral overlap between the absorbance spectra of nitrofurans (NFAs) and the excitation spectrum of MOF 1, the resultant sample exhibits outstandingly sensitive and selective luminescence detectability for NFT (K sv = 3.35 × 104 M-1) and NFZ (K sv = 3.00 × 104 M-1) by quenching phenomenon. More importantly, it can detect NFAs in water from bovine serum samples. The portable MOF film can be easily prepared and used with excellent stability and recursitivity.

elements.content: This work presents an exceptionally stable TbIII metal−organic framework with green luminescence for the highly selective and sensitive detection of antibiotics in aqueous solution with outstanding recyclability.

elements.content: Nitrofurans (NFAs), as a common class of antibiotics with 5-nitrofuran rings, have been universally employed to cure bacterial infections and protozoan in humans and animals, especially nitrofurantoin (NFT) and nitrofurazone (NFZ). Meanwhile, they are also extensively implemented as feed additives for poultry, livestock, and aquaculture to heal bacterial infections (for instance, gastrointestinal enteritis caused by Escherichia coli and Salmonella spp). Although NFAs have a wide range of applications and splendid therapeutic effects, heavy and uncontrolled misuse of them in humans and animals still aggravates a suite of thorny problems, because of encouragement of the spread of antibiotic resistance of pathogenic bacteria. Hence, many countries, particularly developed countries, have adopted a total ban on the use of antibiotics, including The United States, Korea, and other nations. Unfortunately, NFAs are still detected and found in many agricultural products, drinking water, and groundwater, which can infiltrate into human body through the food chains and lead to dozens of diseases. Hence, it is extremely important to explore and develop a high-efficiency method or material to accurately detect such antibiotics in water. Many detection techniques have been developed and applied to detect NFAs in recent decades, including gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry (GC-MS), liquid chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry (LC-MS), luminescence, and micellar electrokinetic capillary chromatography. Among all methods, luminescence sensing has attracted significant attention and interest of scientists to consider it as a promising analysis technique in practice, which is mainly attributed to simple operation, celerity, and high sensitivity.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nitrofurans (NFAs), as a common class of antibiotics with 5-nitrofuran rings, have been universally employed to cure bacterial infections and protozoan in humans and animals, especially nitrofurantoin (NFT) and nitrofurazone (NFZ). Meanwhile, they are also extensively implemented as feed additives for poultry, livestock, and aquaculture to heal bacterial infections (for instance, gastrointestinal enteritis caused by Escherichia coli and Salmonella spp). Although NFAs have a wide range of applications and splendid therapeutic effects, heavy and uncontrolled misuse of them in humans and animals still aggravates a suite of thorny problems, because of encouragement of the spread of antibiotic resistance of pathogenic bacteria. Hence, many countries, particularly developed countries, have adopted a total ban on the use of antibiotics, including The United States, Korea, and other nations. Unfortunately, NFAs are still detected and found in many agricultural products, drinking water, and groundwater, which can infiltrate into human body through the food chains and lead to dozens of diseases. Hence, it is extremely important to explore and develop a high-efficiency method or material to accurately detect such antibiotics in water. Many detection techniques have been developed and applied to detect NFAs in recent decades, including gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry (GC-MS), liquid chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry (LC-MS), luminescence, and micellar electrokinetic capillary chromatography. Among all methods, luminescence sensing has attracted significant attention and interest of scientists to consider it as a promising analysis technique in practice, which is mainly attributed to simple operation, celerity, and high sensitivity.

elements.content: Among various materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as burgeoning porous inorganic–organic hybrid crystalline materials, are attractive to many scientists in fields of materials science and chemistry, because of their fascinating configurations and widespread applications. Particularly, lanthanide-based MOFs (Ln-MOFs) have been already used as high-sensitive luminescent solid materials to monitor targeted analytes through luminescent signal response, including spectral shift and intensity change. Compared with other materials, Ln-MOFs reveal various outstanding advantages, such as high color purity, ocular visible color, large Stokes shift, and long luminescent lifetime. To date, many Ln-MOFs have been successfully prepared and applied to detect small molecules, organic vapor, heavy metal ions, and biomedicine. However, many Ln-MOFs are still unstable in water, similar to that observed with other MOFs, which is mainly attributed to the weak coordinated bond in the coordinated structure. Meanwhile, note that only a few Ln-MOFs have been synthesized and detected antibiotics in aqueous solution. As a result, it is of great significance to design and prepare ultrastable Ln-MOFs for highly selective and sensitive luminescence sensing for antibiotics in aqueous solution.

elements.content: Hence, we chose and synthesized a semirigid bridging ligand 4,4′,4″-s-triazine-1,3,5-triyltri-m-aminobenzoate (H3TATMA) () to further assemble with the TbIII ion by hydrothermal synthesis to fabricate a three-dimensional (3D) material with splendid water stability, {[Tb­(TATMA)­(H2O)·2H2O} n (namely, 1), which is similar to the reported Eu-based MOF. However, experiments involving the Eu-MOF only discuss its catalytic performance for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. In this work, because of the significant green emission under excitation energy and good dispersibility in the water system, MOF 1 exhibits excellent luminescence detectability for NFT and NFZ in aqueous solution, even in the presence of other interfering antibiotics. Furthermore, it can precisely detect NFAs in water from bovine serum samples. Remarkably, the portable MOF film was easily constructed and performed with excellent stability and recyclability.

Legend: C, black; O, red; N, blue; and H, light gray.

Experimental SectionMaterials and Methods

Chemicals and reagents were purchased as analytical-grade and further used directly. Elemental analysis of C, H and N was performed with a CE-440 analyzer (Leeman Laboratories). A Shimadzu DTG-60A system was used simultaneously to obtain thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data in the range of room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in N2. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra, KBr as pellets, were recorded from an Avatar-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer from 4000 cm–1 to 400 cm–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) profiles were all collected at room temperature on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer at a sweep speed of 0.2° 2θ min –1 . All ultraviolet–visible light (UV-vis) absorption spectra were performed on a Shimadzu Model UV-2700 spectrophotometer. Luminescent data were gained from Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer. The morphologies and detailed structure of the ground samples were recorded using a field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) system (JEOL, Model JSM-6700F).

elements.content: Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O (20.0 mg, 0.044 mmol) and H3TATMA (10 mg, 0.02 mmol) were both mixed in a 23.0 mL Teflon-lined autoclave with distilled H2O (3 mL) and aqueous NaOH solution (0.01 M, 50 μL). The resultant mixture was subjected to ultrasonic vibration for 10 min at room temperature, then placed in a heating oven at 170 °C for 3 days. The light-yellow block-shaped crystals were generated and collected after cooling to room temperature; these crystals could be directly washed by distilled water and collected for single-crystal X-ray data analysis. elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Tb(TATMA)(H2O)⋅2H2O} n  (1)

Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O (20.0 mg, 0.044 mmol) and H3TATMA (10 mg, 0.02 mmol) were both mixed in a 23.0 mL Teflon-lined autoclave with distilled H2O (3 mL) and aqueous NaOH solution (0.01 M, 50 μL). The resultant mixture was subjected to ultrasonic vibration for 10 min at room temperature, then placed in a heating oven at 170 °C for 3 days. The light-yellow block-shaped crystals were generated and collected after cooling to room temperature; these crystals could be directly washed by distilled water and collected for single-crystal X-ray data analysis. The yield is ~71%, based on H3TATMA. FT-IR (KBr as pellets): 3432 (br), 1627 (s), 1580 (s), 1552 (s), 1525 (s), 1412 (s), 1351 (s), 1305 (s), 1244 (s), 1124 (s), 997 (s), 893 (s), 758 (s), 680 (s), 597 (s), 410 (s) (see  in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C24H21O9N6Tb: C 41.38, H 3.02, N 12.07%; found: C 41.35, H 3.01, N 12.05%.

elements.content: Prior to the sensing experiments, the as-synthesized samples were dried in air and further milled using a mortar for ∼5 min. The resultant crystal dispersions of 1 (0.1 mg mL –1 ) were achieved by placing 3 mg of ground 1 into 30.0 mL of distilled H2O as a stock mixed dispersion, which was subjected to further ultrasonic agitation for 15 min before it was divided into 3-mL dispersions. The luminescent intensity can be respectively measured in the absence or presence of different analytes including common antibiotics in aqueous solution (1.0 mM), including nitrofurazone (NFZ), nitrofurantoin (NFT), metronidazole (MDZ), dimetridazole (DTZ), sulfamethazine (SMZ), chloramphenicol (CAP), thiamphenicol (THI), and penicillin (PCL). The structures of these antibiotics are provided in in the Supporting Information. The resultant mixture was further stirred for ∼2 min prior to the luminescence measurement, then the emission spectra intensity was detected immediately. Luminescence titration experiments were measured by collecting the emission intensity of 1 in aqueous solutions at different concentrations of NFZ and NFT, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Sensing Experiments

Prior to the sensing experiments, the as-synthesized samples were dried in air and further milled using a mortar for ~5 min. The resultant crystal dispersions of 1 (0.1 mg mL -1 ) were achieved by placing 3 mg of ground 1 into 30.0 mL of distilled H2O as a stock mixed dispersion, which was subjected to further ultrasonic agitation for 15 min before it was divided into 3-mL dispersions. The luminescent intensity can be respectively measured in the absence or presence of different analytes including common antibiotics in aqueous solution (1.0 mM), including nitrofurazone (NFZ), nitrofurantoin (NFT), metronidazole (MDZ), dimetridazole (DTZ), sulfamethazine (SMZ), chloramphenicol (CAP), thiamphenicol (THI), and penicillin (PCL). The structures of these antibiotics are provided in  in the Supporting Information. The resultant mixture was further stirred for ~2 min prior to the luminescence measurement, then the emission spectra intensity was detected immediately. Luminescence titration experiments were measured by collecting the emission intensity of 1 in aqueous solutions at different concentrations of NFZ and NFT, respectively.

elements.content: The reproducibility of MOF 1 for NFZ and NFT was measured in aqueous solution. After the initial quenching experiment, the test material of 1 was recollected by centrifugation and washed with distilled water, which was used in the successive quenching experiment.
elements.clean_text:
Recyclable Luminescence Experiments

The reproducibility of MOF 1 for NFZ and NFT was measured in aqueous solution. After the initial quenching experiment, the test material of 1 was recollected by centrifugation and washed with distilled water, which was used in the successive quenching experiment.

elements.content: Diffraction intensities for the single-crystal 1 were gathered on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (1.54184 Å) by using a ϕ−ω scan approach. The SADABS program was implemented for the semiempirical multiscan attenuation correction. The single-crystal structure can be accurately confirmed by using the direct routine with the SHELXT6 program and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-2015 program through the OLEX2 interface program. Anisotropic parameters were measured for all non-hydrogen atoms. The final crystallographic data are contained in . The selected bond lengths and angles were further provided in in the Supporting Information, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction intensities for the single-crystal 1 were gathered on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (1.54184 Å) by using a ϕ-ω scan approach. The SADABS program was implemented for the semiempirical multiscan attenuation correction. The single-crystal structure can be accurately confirmed by using the direct routine with the SHELXT6 program and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-2015 program through the OLEX2 interface program. Anisotropic parameters were measured for all non-hydrogen atoms. The final crystallographic data are contained in . The selected bond lengths and angles were further provided in  in the Supporting Information, respectively.

From the single-crystal structural result, it clearly illustrated that the three-dimensional (3D) MOF 1 belongs to the triclinic P1̅ space group. As seen in a, the asymmetric unit has only one crystallographically independent TbIII ion, two guest H2O solvent molecules, a terminally coordinated H2O molecule, and one completely deprotonated organic linker for charge balance. The totally deprotonated ligand adopts the same coordinated mode as μ5-η1:η1:η1:η2:η1:η2 to link with five TbIII ions (b). The coordination bond lengths of Tb–O are in the range of 2.3828(1)–2.6154(1) Å (see in the Supporting Information). c shows that the TbIII ion is surrounded by nine O donors from four carboxylate groups of four different TATMA3– ligands and one coordinated H2O molecule. The contiguous independent TbIII centers are linked each other via carboxylate groups from different ligands to construct a one-dimensional (1D) TbIII chain. The Tb···Tb distance is in the range of 4.1692(2) and 4.1707(2) Å. In addition, the adjacent TbIII chains can be periodically expanded by TATMA3– ligands to fabricate a 3D framework (d). The corresponding PXRD profile ascertained the purity of the as-synthesized crystalline (see in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description

From the single-crystal structural result, it clearly illustrated that the three-dimensional (3D) MOF 1 belongs to the triclinic P1̅ space group. As seen in a, the asymmetric unit has only one crystallographically independent TbIII ion, two guest H2O solvent molecules, a terminally coordinated H2O molecule, and one completely deprotonated organic linker for charge balance. The totally deprotonated ligand adopts the same coordinated mode as μ5-η1:η1:η1:η2:η1:η2 to link with five TbIII ions (b). The coordination bond lengths of Tb-O are in the range of 2.3828(1)-2.6154(1) Å (see  in the Supporting Information). c shows that the TbIII ion is surrounded by nine O donors from four carboxylate groups of four different TATMA3- ligands and one coordinated H2O molecule. The contiguous independent TbIII centers are linked each other via carboxylate groups from different ligands to construct a one-dimensional (1D) TbIII chain. The Tb⋅⋅⋅Tb distance is in the range of 4.1692(2) and 4.1707(2) Å. In addition, the adjacent TbIII chains can be periodically expanded by TATMA3- ligands to fabricate a 3D framework (d). The corresponding PXRD profile ascertained the purity of the as-synthesized crystalline (see  in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The thermal stability of the as-synthesized 1 can be investigated in detail by PXRD and TGA measurements. By virtue of the 1D TbIII-chain in MOF 1, we further investigated its stability in detail by soaking the as-synthesized crystals in boiling water for 1 week or immersing them in various pH aqueous solutions (HCl or NaOH) for 12 h at room temperature without stirring. From the PXRD profiles, it obviously illustrates that MOF 1 possesses extraordinary stability in the above harsh conditions (see in the Supporting Information), leading to its multiple potential applications in water system. As seen in in the Supporting Information, the TGA data of as-synthesized 1 at different temperatures illustrated that the main structure of MOF 1 can be kept well below 370 °C. Furthermore, the framework began to disintegrate rapidly as the heating temperature increased.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal and Chemical Stability

The thermal stability of the as-synthesized 1 can be investigated in detail by PXRD and TGA measurements. By virtue of the 1D TbIII-chain in MOF 1, we further investigated its stability in detail by soaking the as-synthesized crystals in boiling water for 1 week or immersing them in various pH aqueous solutions (HCl or NaOH) for 12 h at room temperature without stirring. From the PXRD profiles, it obviously illustrates that MOF 1 possesses extraordinary stability in the above harsh conditions (see  in the Supporting Information), leading to its multiple potential applications in water system. As seen in  in the Supporting Information, the TGA data of as-synthesized 1 at different temperatures illustrated that the main structure of MOF 1 can be kept well below 370 °C. Furthermore, the framework began to disintegrate rapidly as the heating temperature increased.

elements.content: The solid-state luminescence properties of MOF 1 and H3TATMA ligand were both investigated at room temperature. Under excitation energy at 335 nm, 1 demonstrates significantly typical luminescence emission peaks of TbIII at 488, 544, 583, and 620 nm from 5 D 4 → 7 F J (J = 6–3) transition of TbIII (). Especially, the strongest emission band centered at 544 nm comes from a magnetic-dipole-induced 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition to generate strong green luminescence, which can be utilized as a characteristic signal to monitor the sensing ability for various pollutants in aqueous solution. Under similar conditions, the isolated organic ligand reveals a broad emission peak at 426 nm under exciting at 357 nm, which is approximately ascribed to the π → π* or n → π* transition ( in the Supporting Information). In contrast with the emission spectra of H3TATMA and MOF 1, the disappearance of the ligand’s emission peak illustrates that TATMA3– is an excellent antenna linker to sensitize the luminescent property of TbIII ions.
elements.clean_text:
Selective Sensing for NFT and NFZ

The solid-state luminescence properties of MOF 1 and H3TATMA ligand were both investigated at room temperature. Under excitation energy at 335 nm, 1 demonstrates significantly typical luminescence emission peaks of TbIII at 488, 544, 583, and 620 nm from 5 D 4 → 7 F  J  (J = 6-3) transition of TbIII (). Especially, the strongest emission band centered at 544 nm comes from a magnetic-dipole-induced 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition to generate strong green luminescence, which can be utilized as a characteristic signal to monitor the sensing ability for various pollutants in aqueous solution. Under similar conditions, the isolated organic ligand reveals a broad emission peak at 426 nm under exciting at 357 nm, which is approximately ascribed to the π → π* or n → π* transition ( in the Supporting Information). In contrast with the emission spectra of H3TATMA and MOF 1, the disappearance of the ligand's emission peak illustrates that TATMA3- is an excellent antenna linker to sensitize the luminescent property of TbIII ions.

elements.content: Because of the remarkably green luminescence and high stability ( in the Supporting Information), it drives us to investigate and explore the luminescence detection capability of MOF 1 to multiple antibiotics in water. The resultant crystal dispersions of ground 1 (0.1 mg mL –1 ) were achieved and prepared before the measurements. The morphology and dispersion of the ground sample for sensing experiments was measured and observed using SEM tests, illustrating that the sizes of most of the ground samples were <2 μm without uniform morphology (see in the Supporting Information). As displayed in , the luminescence signals of 1 were collected in the presence of different antibiotics in aqueous solution (0.1 mM), including NFZ, NFT, MDZ, DTZ, SMZ, CAP, THI, and PCL. Interestingly, it is obviously found that MOF 1 shows a remarkable luminescence quenching in NFZ and NFT solutions. The quenching efficiency can be quantitatively estimated by [(I 0 – I)/I 0] using the luminescent intensity of the highest peak at 544 nm. The corresponding largest quenching efficiencies are 78% for NFZ and 80% for NFT, respectively. Nevertheless, the quenching efficiencies for the other antibiotics are significantly lower than NFZ and NFT (see , inset). The results clearly indicated that MOF 1 can be considered as a luminescence detector for the selective recognition of NFZ and NFT in aqueous solution.

elements.content: To further gain an insight into the detectability of 1 for NFZ and NFT, the luminescence titration trial of 1 was performed by gradually adding NFZ and NFT in the test solutions, respectively. As displayed in a and b, the luminescence intensity of 1 remarkably appeared to show luminescent quench phenomenon as the concentration of NFZ and NFT increased. Meanwhile, the quenching efficiency of MOF 1 for NFZ and NFT can be obtained quantitatively in the low concentration range with linear dependence, using the Stern–Volmer (S–V) equation: I 0/I = 1 + K sv [M], where I 0 is the luminescent intensity of 1 with NFZ and NFT and I is the luminescent intensity of 1 without NFZ and NFT; [M] represents the molar concentration of NFZ and NFT, and K sv is the quenching constant (M–1) used to evaluate the detection effect. The linear correlations for NFZ and NFT were visibly determined for the results of ((I 0/I) – 1) versus the concentrations in the range from 0 to 5 μM in a and b, because the static quenching mechanism is the dominant factor at low detectable concentrations. The calculated K sv values for NFZ and NFT are 3.00 × 104 M–1 and 3.35 × 104 M–1, indicating that MOF 1 is almost the most efficient luminescent MOFs-based sensor for antibiotics (see in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The signal responses of 1 to NFZ and NFT in aqueous solutions were collected at different time intervals (a and b). Once NFZ or NFT was added, the luminescent intensity of MOF 1 started to rapidly reduce and achieve a minimum value after 40 s, which can further last a long time. The results manifested that luminescent response of 1 for NFZ and NFT can be quickly completed in a very short time. Meanwhile, the anti-interference performance is also a remarkably important factor for MOF 1. The dispersions of as-synthesized 1 (0.3 mg) were placed into a 3 mL aqueous solution with mixed NFZ or NFT (0.1 mM), and equimolar amounts of other antibiotics (SMZ, PCL, THI, CAP, DTZ, and MDZ). The results showed that the luminescence intensity of 1 only produced a slight reduction after the addition of disturbed antibiotics, whereas the emission peaks were immediately quenched after adding equimolar amounts of NFZ or NFT. The anti-interference trials demonstrated that MOF 1 can serve as a highly selective luminescent sensor for NFZ or NFT, even in the presence of several other antibiotics (c and d).

elements.content: Recyclability is a significantly critical ability for detecting NFT or NFZ in the practical application. The luminescent crystalline 1 is feasibly recollected from the aqueous solution by centrifigation and washing by distilled water. The collected crystals can be redispersed in the aqueous solution for the continuous monitoring experiments. The luminescent property of recycled 1 can be maintained very well. Remarkably, MOF 1 can be continuously recollected and reused to detect NFZ or NFT in aqueous solutions at least 10 cycles (), suggesting that 1 has extraordinary recyclability and outstanding stability in actual applications as a luminescent detection material. The PXRD patterns of recycled MOF 1 further ascertained that the original skeleton can be retained completely (see in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Recyclability of MOF 1 

Recyclability is a significantly critical ability for detecting NFT or NFZ in the practical application. The luminescent crystalline 1 is feasibly recollected from the aqueous solution by centrifigation and washing by distilled water. The collected crystals can be redispersed in the aqueous solution for the continuous monitoring experiments. The luminescent property of recycled 1 can be maintained very well. Remarkably, MOF 1 can be continuously recollected and reused to detect NFZ or NFT in aqueous solutions at least 10 cycles (), suggesting that 1 has extraordinary recyclability and outstanding stability in actual applications as a luminescent detection material. The PXRD patterns of recycled MOF 1 further ascertained that the original skeleton can be retained completely (see  in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Because of the overuse of NFAs as feed additives for poultry, swine, and cattle, it will potentially have harmful effects on daily human health. Hence, it is urgently needed to efficiently detect NFAs in domestic animals. It remarkably encourages us to investigate MOF 1 for monitoring NFT, as a model, in the real bovine serum samples via luminescence response. The test samples were added to a certain amount of standard NFT solution. The measurement results were totally summarized in , which significantly illustrated that the NFT recovery of MOF 1 can be retained in the range from 98.6% to 102%. Furthermore, it was found that the relative standard deviation (RSD) of NFT for MOF 1 was <4.2%. All of the above data illustrated that the resultant material has potentially practical application value in the area of food safety.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of NFAs in Bovine Serum

Because of the overuse of NFAs as feed additives for poultry, swine, and cattle, it will potentially have harmful effects on daily human health. Hence, it is urgently needed to efficiently detect NFAs in domestic animals. It remarkably encourages us to investigate MOF 1 for monitoring NFT, as a model, in the real bovine serum samples via luminescence response. The test samples were added to a certain amount of standard NFT solution. The measurement results were totally summarized in , which significantly illustrated that the NFT recovery of MOF 1 can be retained in the range from 98.6% to 102%. Furthermore, it was found that the relative standard deviation (RSD) of NFT for MOF 1 was <4.2%. All of the above data illustrated that the resultant material has potentially practical application value in the area of food safety.

The ground MOF 1 was uniformly dispersed in gelatinous glue and spread on a glass sheet. The glass substrate was heated at 100 °C for 2 h to fabricate a luminescent film of MOF 1, which can be easily peeled away from the glass base (see a–c). To further investigate the practical application of the obtained membrane, aqueous NFT solution (0.5 mM), as a detectable model, was applied to explore the sensor capacity of this luminescent film of MOF 1. As seen in d–f, the strong green luminescence of MOF 1 film immediately disappeared with the gradual immersion into the NFT aqueous solution under the hand-held ultraviolet lamp at 365 nm. More interesting, the green luminescence can be rapidly regenerated after removal from the test aqueous solution (see g and h). The blank experiments of film and powder in pure water were investigated and the green luminescence was maintained to further illustrate the luminescent sensor ability for NFT (see in the Supporting Information). As found in , the luminescence intensity and quenching effect of this MOF 1 film can be essentially preserved after applying this film for at least five cycles. These outstanding results indicate that the MOF 1 film can meet the high requirements of authentic detection and recovery for such NFAs antibiotics.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Film of MOF 1

The ground MOF 1 was uniformly dispersed in gelatinous glue and spread on a glass sheet. The glass substrate was heated at 100 °C for 2 h to fabricate a luminescent film of MOF 1, which can be easily peeled away from the glass base (see a-c). To further investigate the practical application of the obtained membrane, aqueous NFT solution (0.5 mM), as a detectable model, was applied to explore the sensor capacity of this luminescent film of MOF 1. As seen in d-f, the strong green luminescence of MOF 1 film immediately disappeared with the gradual immersion into the NFT aqueous solution under the hand-held ultraviolet lamp at 365 nm. More interesting, the green luminescence can be rapidly regenerated after removal from the test aqueous solution (see g and h). The blank experiments of film and powder in pure water were investigated and the green luminescence was maintained to further illustrate the luminescent sensor ability for NFT (see  in the Supporting Information). As found in , the luminescence intensity and quenching effect of this MOF 1 film can be essentially preserved after applying this film for at least five cycles. These outstanding results indicate that the MOF 1 film can meet the high requirements of authentic detection and recovery for such NFAs antibiotics.

elements.content: It is remarkably important to understand the luminescence quenching mechanism and highly selective detection capability of MOF 1 to explore and exploit more-efficient materials for the feasible applications. From the previous investigations, it is found that many luminescence quenching phenomena are mainly caused by four representative cases: structure collapse, guest adsorption, host–guest weak interaction, and photocompetitive absorption. From the PXRD profiles of the reused MOF 1 after 10 cycles (see in the Supporting Information), it obviously demonstrates that the luminescence quenching is not ascribed to the framework collapse. Second, the no-porous structure and the fast regeneration of MOF 1 both exhibit that the luminescence quenching does not come from guest adsorption. The luminescence quenching performance is usually generated by the electron transfer from conduction bands (CB) of luminescent sensor materials to lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of analytes, because of the higher energy levels of CBs than the LUMO levels of the detected analytes. Herein, the significantly different band gaps between the CB of MOF 1 and the LUMOs of testable antibiotic may be likely to cause distinctly diverse driving forces for the electron transfer between host and guest. As shown in in the Supporting Information, the corresponding LUMO energy levels of the selected antibiotics are basically consistent with the quenching results (NFAs > nitroimidazoles > others). Notably, the LUMO energy levels of CAP and NFAs are very similar to each other, while MOF 1 has entirely different luminescent quenching responses. The results clearly exhibited that the electron transfer between host and guest is not the unique contributing cause for the luminescence quenching. Meanwhile, the strong absorption bands of NFT and NFZ both significantly overlap with the excitation spectrum of MOF 1 (). The excitation energy is easily competitively absorbed by NFZ or NFT molecules to distinctly reduce energy transfer to MOF 1, to produce remarkably luminescent quenching. Therefore, the luminescent quenching of MOF 1 is probably ascribed to the competitive absorption of excitation energy between MOF 1 and antibiotics, especially NFZ and NFT. In addition, the weak intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions also may exist between MOF 1 and these antibiotics, thanks to the presence of various hydrogen-bonding donors and acceptors.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism of Luminescence Quenching

It is remarkably important to understand the luminescence quenching mechanism and highly selective detection capability of MOF 1 to explore and exploit more-efficient materials for the feasible applications. From the previous investigations, it is found that many luminescence quenching phenomena are mainly caused by four representative cases: structure collapse, guest adsorption, host-guest weak interaction, and photocompetitive absorption. From the PXRD profiles of the reused MOF 1 after 10 cycles (see  in the Supporting Information), it obviously demonstrates that the luminescence quenching is not ascribed to the framework collapse. Second, the no-porous structure and the fast regeneration of MOF 1 both exhibit that the luminescence quenching does not come from guest adsorption. The luminescence quenching performance is usually generated by the electron transfer from conduction bands (CB) of luminescent sensor materials to lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of analytes, because of the higher energy levels of CBs than the LUMO levels of the detected analytes. Herein, the significantly different band gaps between the CB of MOF 1 and the LUMOs of testable antibiotic may be likely to cause distinctly diverse driving forces for the electron transfer between host and guest. As shown in  in the Supporting Information, the corresponding LUMO energy levels of the selected antibiotics are basically consistent with the quenching results (NFAs > nitroimidazoles > others). Notably, the LUMO energy levels of CAP and NFAs are very similar to each other, while MOF 1 has entirely different luminescent quenching responses. The results clearly exhibited that the electron transfer between host and guest is not the unique contributing cause for the luminescence quenching. Meanwhile, the strong absorption bands of NFT and NFZ both significantly overlap with the excitation spectrum of MOF 1 (). The excitation energy is easily competitively absorbed by NFZ or NFT molecules to distinctly reduce energy transfer to MOF 1, to produce remarkably luminescent quenching. Therefore, the luminescent quenching of MOF 1 is probably ascribed to the competitive absorption of excitation energy between MOF 1 and antibiotics, especially NFZ and NFT. In addition, the weak intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions also may exist between MOF 1 and these antibiotics, thanks to the presence of various hydrogen-bonding donors and acceptors.

elements.content: In conclusion, a novel three-dimensional (3D) Tb-MOF with green luminescence has been successfully achieved via hydrothermal methods, illustrating outstanding ultrastability and high selectivity to NFZ and NFT in aqueous solution via naked luminescence quenching. The terminated K sv values of NFZ and NFT are calculated to be ∼3.0 × 104 and 3.35 × 104 M–1, respectively. More important, MOF 1 can be feasibly fabricated into a portable luminescent film to directly monitor NFZ and NFT in aqueous solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, a novel three-dimensional (3D) Tb-MOF with green luminescence has been successfully achieved via hydrothermal methods, illustrating outstanding ultrastability and high selectivity to NFZ and NFT in aqueous solution via naked luminescence quenching. The terminated K sv values of NFZ and NFT are calculated to be ~3.0 × 104 and 3.35 × 104 M-1, respectively. More important, MOF 1 can be feasibly fabricated into a portable luminescent film to directly monitor NFZ and NFT in aqueous solutions.

cln_elements.content: Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O (20.0 mg, 0.044 mmol) and H3TATMA (10 mg, 0.02 mmol) were both mixed in a 23.0 mL Teflon-lined autoclave with distilled H2O (3 mL) and aqueous NaOH solution (0.01 M, 50 μL). The resultant mixture was subjected to ultrasonic vibration for 10 min at room temperature, then placed in a heating oven at 170 °C for 3 days. The light-yellow block-shaped crystals were generated and collected after cooling to room temperature; these crystals could be directly washed by distilled water and collected for single-crystal X-ray data analysis. The yield is ∼71%, based on H3TATMA. FT-IR (KBr as pellets): 3432 (br), 1627 (s), 1580 (s), 1552 (s), 1525 (s), 1412 (s), 1351 (s), 1305 (s), 1244 (s), 1124 (s), 997 (s), 893 (s), 758 (s), 680 (s), 597 (s), 410 (s) (see in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C24H21O9N6Tb: C 41.38, H 3.02, N 12.07%; found: C 41.35, H 3.01, N 12.05%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Tb(TATMA)(H2O)⋅2H2O} n  (1)

Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O (20.0 mg, 0.044 mmol) and H3TATMA (10 mg, 0.02 mmol) were both mixed in a 23.0 mL Teflon-lined autoclave with distilled H2O (3 mL) and aqueous NaOH solution (0.01 M, 50 μL). The resultant mixture was subjected to ultrasonic vibration for 10 min at room temperature, then placed in a heating oven at 170 °C for 3 days. The light-yellow block-shaped crystals were generated and collected after cooling to room temperature; these crystals could be directly washed by distilled water and collected for single-crystal X-ray data analysis. The yield is ~71%, based on H3TATMA. FT-IR (KBr as pellets): 3432 (br), 1627 (s), 1580 (s), 1552 (s), 1525 (s), 1412 (s), 1351 (s), 1305 (s), 1244 (s), 1124 (s), 997 (s), 893 (s), 758 (s), 680 (s), 597 (s), 410 (s) (see  in the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for C24H21O9N6Tb: C 41.38, H 3.02, N 12.07%; found: C 41.35, H 3.01, N 12.05%.

cln_elements.content: The solid-state luminescence properties of MOF 1 and H3TATMA ligand were both investigated at room temperature. Under excitation energy at 335 nm, 1 demonstrates significantly typical luminescence emission peaks of TbIII at 488, 544, 583, and 620 nm from 5 D 4 → 7 F J (J = 6–3) transition of TbIII (). Especially, the strongest emission band centered at 544 nm comes from a magnetic-dipole-induced 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition to generate strong green luminescence, which can be utilized as a characteristic signal to monitor the sensing ability for various pollutants in aqueous solution. Under similar conditions, the isolated organic ligand reveals a broad emission peak at 426 nm under exciting at 357 nm, which is approximately ascribed to the π → π* or n → π* transition ( in the Supporting Information). In contrast with the emission spectra of H3TATMA and MOF 1, the disappearance of the ligand’s emission peak illustrates that TATMA3– is an excellent antenna linker to sensitize the luminescent property of TbIII ions.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Selective Sensing for NFT and NFZ

The solid-state luminescence properties of MOF 1 and H3TATMA ligand were both investigated at room temperature. Under excitation energy at 335 nm, 1 demonstrates significantly typical luminescence emission peaks of TbIII at 488, 544, 583, and 620 nm from 5 D 4 → 7 F  J  (J = 6-3) transition of TbIII (). Especially, the strongest emission band centered at 544 nm comes from a magnetic-dipole-induced 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition to generate strong green luminescence, which can be utilized as a characteristic signal to monitor the sensing ability for various pollutants in aqueous solution. Under similar conditions, the isolated organic ligand reveals a broad emission peak at 426 nm under exciting at 357 nm, which is approximately ascribed to the π → π* or n → π* transition ( in the Supporting Information). In contrast with the emission spectra of H3TATMA and MOF 1, the disappearance of the ligand's emission peak illustrates that TATMA3- is an excellent antenna linker to sensitize the luminescent property of TbIII ions.

peak spectrum.condition: room temperature, excitation energy at 335 nm
